statement.p: In Preview Activity, we reasoned graphically to sketch the derivative of g(x) = 2^x. The following questions remind us of some of the key ideas of sketching the graph of the derivative, given a graph of the original function.

li.p: Let q(x) = 2 - (x-1)^2, and use a graphing utility to plot this quadratic function. At what value(s) of x is q'(x) = 0? For what values of x is q'(x) positive? For what values of x is q'(x) negative?
*QUESTION*: would it be helpful to provide axes for students to sketch q and q'?
Let f(x) = \sin(x), and use a graphing utility to plot this trigonometric function. At what value(s) of x is f'(x) = 0? For what values of x is f'(x) positive? For what values of x is f'(x) negative?
Let g(x) = \cos(x), and use a graphing utility to plot this trigonometric function. At what value(s) of x is g'(x) = 0? For what values of x is g'(x) positive? For what values of x is g'(x) negative?
